poem:
Waiting for Care

In the sterile halls,  
time slows to a crawl—  
hope, worn thin,  
like old gauze, frayed.  

Knees creak  
against the clock,  
a watchful pulse—  
18 weeks there,  
60 here.  

Promises dissolve  
in antiseptic air;  
private doorways  
beckon:  
swift, comforting,  
an expeditious balm.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A chaotic NHS is why people now ‘go private’ | Letters Frances Ryan’s article rings familiar bells (Young people want to ‘go private’ – I’m a lifelong supporter of the NHS, but I can see why, 20 August). I have been waiting 60 weeks for a partial knee replacement. The hospital website and the NHS website say “average patient waiting time 18 weeks”. However, at every stage my wait has been beset by avoidable delays: two". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
